snippet: South Carolina will not fight rulings that have blocked key parts of a law requiring police to check people’s immigration status during routine stops.
abstract: South Carolina says it will no longer defend key part of 2011 law requiring police to check people’s immigration status during routine stops; state officials and coalition of immigrant right groups agree to settle legal dispute over law that was centered on its 'show me your papers' section.
lead_paragraph: South Carolina will not fight rulings that have blocked key parts of a law requiring police to check people’s immigration status during routine stops.

headline.main: South Carolina ‘Show Me Papers’ Dispute Is Settled
